Article Surface engineering of TeO x modification on MoVTeNbO creates a high-performance catalyst for oxidation of toluene homologues to aldehydes Changshun Deng a 1 Bingqing Ge a 1 Jun Yao a Taotao Zhao a Chenyang Shen a Zhewei Zhang a Tao Wang b Xiangke Guo a Nianhua Xue a Xuefeng Guo a Luming Peng a Yan Zhu a Weiping Ding a * a Key Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, Jiangsu, China Key Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing Jiangsu 210023 China Key Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, Jiangsu, China b Jiangsu Meso Catalytic Materials Technology Co., Ltd, Suzhou 215634, Jiangsu, China Jiangsu Meso Catalytic Materials Technology Co., Ltd Suzhou Jiangsu 215634 China Jiangsu Meso Catalytic Materials Technology Co., Ltd, Suzhou 215634, Jiangsu, China * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed equally to this work. The heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of toluene by O2 is an inherently safe and green route for production of benzaldehyde, but after more than fifty years of effort, it remains a great challenge. Here, we report the best heterogeneous catalyst, TeO x /MoVTeNbO, up to now for the green oxidation of toluene by O2 to benzaldehyde, balancing the catalyst activity, selectivity, and stability. The deposition of TeO x endows the MoVTeNbO composite oxide with entirely new property for toluene oxidation and the surface engineering mechanism has been fully explained. The discrete TeO x clusters on the surface, shielding the nonselective oxidation sites that interact strongly with the benzene ring of toluene molecule, allows toluene molecule to chemically adsorb to the surface perpendicularly and the methyl is then prone to oxidation to aldehyde on the reshaped selective oxidation sites, where V=O is the main active species responsible for continuously extracting hydrogen from methyl and implanting oxygen to form benzaldehyde. The TeO x clusters participate in this reaction through variable valences and stabilize benzaldehyde by couple interaction with the –CHO group of benzaldehyde, thereby achieving high selectivity to benzaldehyde (>95%). The extended works indicate that the catalytic mechanism is effective in a series of selective oxidation of toluene homologues to corresponding aldehydes. Graphical Abstract The TeO x clusters post-impregnated on the surface of MoVTeNbO complex oxides, surrounding V=O site, significantly alter the product of oxidation of toluene, changing from maleic anhydride to benzaldehyde, by regulating the adsorption configuration of toluene and stabilizing benzaldehyde. Keywords Surface engineering TeO x /MoVTeNbO Toluene oxidation Benzaldehyde Molecular oxygen 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of hydrocarbons to oxygenates is a class of extremely important chemical reactions, which introduce oxygen into hydrocarbons and produce versatile and more valuable chemicals [1–8]. As a typical example, the green oxidation of toluene by O2 to benzaldehyde is a high-value reaction in industry but represents a long-standing challenge in chemistry [9–12]. Chlorination of toluene followed by hydrolysis and the homogeneous oxidation of toluene in transition metallic ions containing acetic acid by O2 under assistance of radical initiators (Scheme 1(a) ) constitutes the main two routes in current industry for production of benzaldehyde, having serious corrosion and environmental problems, and the residual trace halogens are harmful to its uses in medicine, spices, and food [13–16]. In past five-six decades, numerous heterogeneous catalysts or processes have been investigated on the topic but the progress has been very limited. Either the conversion or selectivity is not high and the sum of them is hardly more than one hundred, due to the easier continuous oxidation of benzaldehyde in reaction [17–25]. To date, the best catalyst may be the bimetallic PdAu reported in 2011 for toluene oxidation in liquid phase by O2, the main product is benzyl benzoate with a small amount of over-oxidized products [9]. Highly selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde by O2, no involvement of any halogens, has been long-term desired but never successful in industrial processes for more than half a century [26]. Thus, to develop efficient and highly selective catalysts and green processes, using fixed bed reactor under ambient pressure, has extremely scientific importance and industrial significance. MoVTeNbO complex oxides, one of the family of Mo–V-based M1 oxides (including Mo–V and Mo–V–Te(Sb)–Nb–O), is by far the most promising catalyst for ethane oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) and also emerges excellent catalytic performance in selective (amm)oxidation of propane to acrylic acid or acrylonitrile [27–30]. The catalytically active sites are associated with an ensemble, surrounded by a framework of pentagonal units {(Mo,V)5Nb}, of 5 V- and Mo-centered octahedra in S2, S4, and S7 positions, forming (TeO)1−x ·(Mo, V, Nb)10O28 crystalline phase by stacking along the out-of-plane direction, i.e., the so-called M1 phase (Fig. 1(a) ) [31,32]. For ODH, the ability to extract the first H atom is ascribed to the transformation of V=O groups to O− radicals through charge transfer resonance (Fig. 1(b)), and the reactive V5+ cations isolated within the structure can efficiently prevent over-oxidation of specific products generated at the isolated sites [33,34]. For ethane ODH, the distortion energy required for the consecutive generation of undesired C–O bonds during the reaction is limited by steric hindrance, which facilitates the formation of epoxidation transition states and promotes high ethylene selectivity [35]. In propane ODH, however, the dehydrogenations of propane to propylene are slow steps, while the continuous oxidation of propylene to acrylic acid is much faster in kinetics than the former, which is due to the much lower dissociation energy of allylic C–H bonds (371 kJ·mol−1) than that of propenyl C–H bonds (454 kJ·mol−1) [36,37]. Therefore, it is very difficult to control the catalytic oxidation of propane to propylene using MoVTeNbO complex oxides with the M1 phase, including the control on the oxidation to acrolein [38]. Meanwhile, MoVTeNbO complex oxides are structurally sensitive catalysts reflected in the significant discrepancies in catalytic performances caused by small differences in microstructure. It has been demonstrated that the preparation process has a significant impact on the microstructure of the oxides, such as morphology, crystal phase, composition, surface element valence states, and so on [27,39–41]. The active V5+ species, part of the pentameric ensembles (S4)2-S2-(S7)2 (Fig. 1(b)), have been recognized responsible to the activity for selective oxidation of alkanes [31,33,34,39,42]. More significantly, it has been reported that the absence of Te would lead to the rearrangement of electron density around the pentameric unit and increase the oxidation tendency of V4+ to V5+, thus increasing the activity of the catalysts; and significant improvement in the selectivity of alkanes oxidation has been reported when Te oxides are present as the surface species at submonolayer coverage [43,44]. Considering the partial similarity in electronic states between the benzyl and allyl group, it can be conceived that the MoVTeNbO complex oxides would be highly effective for selective oxidation of toluene using O2 as oxidant. In an exploratory work, we experimentally synthesized the M1 phase MoVTeNbO complex oxides (hereafter named as MVTN, Fig. 1(c)) through an improved hydrothermal process and used for toluene oxidation, however, maleic anhydride and CO x are observed as the main products. The mechanism was revealed through density functional theory (DFT) calculations and verified by in-situ spectral characterization, in which the toluene adsorbed on MVTN surface in a lying down form with its π orbitals strongly interacted with the catalyst surface, leading to ring-opening oxidation to maleic anhydride. The desorption energy of benzaldehyde from MVTN surface is calculated as high as 1.47 eV, implying the difficulty to obtain benzaldehyde. Combined the knowledge of MoVTeNbO complex oxides [45] and the abovementioned results of calculations and characterizations, it is realized that we are able to reform the surface of MoVTeNbO complex oxides to weaken its interactions with the ring of toluene by surface engineering, e.g., placing TeO x species. It has been found by DFT calculations that the TeO x clusters, in suitable surface density, surround the V=O sites on the surface of MVTN (hereafter named as TeO x /MVTN, Fig. 1(d)) through self-organization. With such surface configurations, the interactions of π orbitals of toluene with the catalyst surface are greatly weakened and the vertical adsorption of toluene on the catalyst surface becomes the main manner. The desorption energy of benzaldehyde was calculated as 0.64 eV, comparable to that of toluene (0.64 eV), suggesting the very easy desorption of benzaldehyde. Then, the mechanism of toluene oxidation to benzaldehyde is described as that the V=O center is responsible for the continuous extraction of hydrogens from the methyl of toluene, with the methyl carbon bonded to the oxygen of surrounding TeO x clusters. The TeO x clusters are helpful to the final desorption of benzaldehyde. Verified by experimental, we found the TeO x /MVTN catalyst, in a fixed bed reactor under ambient pressure with reactants of toluene and O2, delivers a high selectivity of >95% to benzaldehyde at remarkable toluene conversion up to 24% at 400 °C and also exhibits excellent catalyst stability (>500 h). More convincingly, the vertical adsorption of toluene with its methyl downward to TeO x /MVTN surface during toluene reaction is confirmed by the analysis of in-situ DRIFTS of the adsorption of toluene and benzaldehyde. Noteworthy that the novel reaction mechanism is effective for the selective oxidations of a series of toluene homologues to aldehydes, most of them show high selectivity and activity, for example, the selectivity for the oxidation of p-chlorotoluene to p-chlorobenzaldehyde exceeds 99% and the conversion is greater than 28% (Scheme 1(b)). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The MVTN catalyst was prepared through a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method followed by calcination and purification with H2O2 aqueous solution. Typically, 12.36 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 2.85 g of VOSO4, and 3.70 g of H6TeO6 were added into 90 mL of deionized water with vigorous stirring and heated to 80 °C for 0.5 h, as solution A; 2.54 g of C4H4NNbO9·nH2O was added into 40 mL of deionized water with vigorous stirring and heated to 80 °C for 0.2 h, as solution B. Then, solution B was slowly poured into solution A with vigorous stirring for 0.5 h when they were reduced to 40 °C. Next, the above slurry was transferred into a 200 mL of Teflon autoclave and kept at 175 °C for 48 h. The obtained black sediment was collected after washing several times with deionized water and ethanol and then dried at 70 °C overnight in oven. The collected powder was calcined at 250 °C in air for 2 h and then at 600 °C in Ar for 2 h. Finally, the solid was purified with 7.5% H2O2 aqueous solution at 60 °C for 3 h followed by washing and drying to form MoVTeNbO catalyst. The TeO x /MVTN catalyst was prepared through an impregnation method. The TeO x loading was defined as the weight ratio of TeO x /(TeO x + MVTN) and the loading of TeO x was 8 wt%. The final catalyst was obtained by calcining the impregnation powder at 450 °C in Ar for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) characterizations of the catalysts were tested on a FEI-TALOS-F200X at a voltage of 200 kV and JEOL JEM-6300F system, respectively. Raman spectroscopy was collected on a Renishaw Invia spectrometer with an excitation laser wavelength of 488 nm. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was carried out on a Bruker EMX system at 20 K. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on a NEXUS870 spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results were measured on a PHI 5000 VersaProbe with an Al Kα excitation source. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) were performed on a chemisorption instrument (Tianjin XQ TP-5076). The TPR signals were collected in a flow of 5 vol% H2/N2 from 100 to 800 °C (heating rate: 10 °C·min−1) after the catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C in He for 1 h. For TPD, the catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h and then reduced to 100 °C under He atmosphere. At this temperature, the catalyst was treated with NH3 for 0.5 h and then purged with He to remove residual NH3. After that, the TPD signals were collected in flowing He from 100 to 600 °C (heating rate: 10 °C·min−1). Mo, V, and Te K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) for the catalysts were collected at the dynamic beamline of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed on an instrument of Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS50. Firstly, the powder catalyst was put into a small crucible, mounted in a quarts IR cell, and pretreated at 350 °C (MVTN) or 400 °C (TeO x /MVTN) in flowing O2 (5 mL·min−1) and N2 (20 mL·min−1) for 1 h. During the in-situ DRIFT process, the resolution of 4 cm−1 with 64 scans was set to collect the spectra. The background was initially recorded under the same gas conditions until the spectrum become steady. Subsequently, 1 μL·min−1 of toluene vaporized in the line was injected into the above flowing stream of O2 and N2, and the spectrum was collected at an interval of 5 min. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic performance of toluene oxidation was tested using a quartz reactor (4 mm i.d.). For a typical procedure, 0.3 g of catalyst was pretreated at 250 °C in flowing O2 (5 mL·min−1) and N2 (20 mL·min−1) for 1 h. Subsequently, 1 μL·min−1 of toluene vaporized in the line was introduced into the above flowing stream and the catalytic performance of the catalyst was measured from 250 to 450 °C at an interval of 25 °C. The products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC-9860) equipped with a flame ionization detector (SE-54 column) and two thermal conductivity detectors (Paropak Q and molecular sieves 5A columns). The conversion of toluene as well as the selectivity of benzaldehyde and CO x were calculated as follows: X C6H5CH3 = (C6H5CH3in ‒ C6H5CH3out)/C6H5CH3in × 100% where C6H5CH3in and C6H5CH3out represent the molar fraction of toluene at the inlet and outlet, respectively. S C6H5CHO = f C6H5CHO A C6H5CHO/[f CH3CH(OC2H5)2 A CH3CH(OC2H5)2 + f C4H2O3 A C4H2O3 + f C6H5COOH A C6H5COOH + f HO2CCH2CO2C2H5 A HO2CCH2CO2C2H5 + (f CO A CO + f CO2 A CO2)/7] × 100% S COx = [(f CO A CO + f CO2 A CO2)/7]/(C6H5CH3in ‒ C6H5CH3out) × 100% CH3CH(OC2H5)2, C4H2O3 (maleic anhydride), C6H5CHO, C6H5COOH, and HO2CCH2CH2CO2C2H5 are the five organic products produced in this work. The formulas of the selectivity of other organic products are displayed in Supplementary Methods. 2.4 DFT calculations DFT calculations were carried out using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in the nonlocal van der Waals density functional (vdW-DF2) [46–49]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials were used to calculate the electronic structures and a plane wave cutoff energy equal to 400, 520, and 600 eV. The Brillouin zone was sampled with Γ-centered Monkhorst Pack K-point mesh [50]. The model for bulk M1-phase oxides (MoVTeNb complex oxides) consists of one identical layers along the [001] direction, leading to 21.37 × 26.94 × 22.42 Å3 orthorhombic supercells [35]. The convergence of the total energy was considered to be achieved until two iterated steps with energy difference less than 10−4 eV. All atoms were fully relaxed during the geometry optimization until the force on each atom was at least lower than 0.05 eV·Å−1. Structures of transition states were determined using improved dimer calculations [51,52]. 2.5 MD simulations MD simulations were conducted using the Forcite module within the Materials Studio software package. The structure of MVTN was adapted from the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD) and expanded to a 5 × 10 × 3 supercell according to experimental atomic ratios [35,53]. Atomic charges were determined using the Qeq method [54]. TeO x clusters were loaded on the surface of the 5 × 10 × 3 supercell to create partially covered TeO x /MVTN structures. Structural optimization was performed on both MVTN and TeO x /MVTN models to minimize energy. Molecules of toluene, N2, and O2 were introduced onto the surfaces of both catalysts according to different feed compositions using the Amorphous Cell module and further optimized for equilibrium positions. MD simulations were conducted using the universal force field (UFF) under the NVT ensemble for 1 ns. The temperature was controlled at 400 °C using the Nose temperature coupling method, with the time step of 1 fs. Trajectory frames were extracted and analyzed to calculate the diffusion rates of toluene. The MSD of toluene was then computed to demonstrate its mobility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Theoretical insights of benzaldehyde selectivity Fig. S1 lists the composition of catalyst MVTN synthesized in this work in atomic ratios of Mo:V:Te:Nb = 28:4:1:11, with relatively lower vanadium and tellurium but higher niobium contents than documented catalysts (Fig. 1(a)) [33,35,37]. Based on its practical composition and the structure of pentameric ensembles (S4)2-S2-(S7)2, as shown in Fig. 1(b), totally 15 configurations (C1−C15) of the MVTN can be identified with M1 crystal structure, given in Fig. S2. Among them, the C9 configuration (also shown before as Fig. 1(c)) is determined as the optimal of MVTN due to its lowest energy (Fig. S3). Guided by theoretical predictions, it is found that the surface density of TeO x on MVTN has a significant impact on the adsorption configuration of toluene (Figs. 2(a) and S4). As shown in Fig. 2(a), on the surface of MVTN, toluene tends to be adsorbed in a lying down form, manifested as 0.23 eV more exothermic adsorption for the lying flat than the vertical manner. With the increase in TeO x density on MVTN, the adsorption configuration of toluene gradually changes from lying flat to vertical adsorption which can be ascribed to more intensive steric effect. Over TeO x /MVTN, the differences in the adsorption energy between the two manners of adsorption are 0.23 eV (0 wt% of TeO x ), ‒0.1 eV (4 wt% of TeO x , 0.17/nm2), and ‒0.15 eV (8 wt% of TeO x , 0.34/nm2). The loading of 8 wt% of TeO x corresponds to the optimal density of TeO x clusters on MVTN. The diagram of energy steps involving 10 intermediates of toluene oxidation is obtained using DFT calculations to demonstrate the potential mechanisms of reaction over the two catalysts MVTN and TeO x /MVTN (Figs. 2(b‒d)). On the surface of MVTN, toluene is adsorbed in a lying down form and one hydrogen on the methyl group is abstracted to the oxygen site on the nearby V, forming V–OH. At this time, the intermediate benzyl is bonded onto the lattice oxygen of MVTN, forming C6H5–CH2–O–V (FS1), with an energy barrier of 1.08 eV. Then, the second hydrogen on the methylene of intermediate FS1 continues to be extracted to the V–OH site, forming adsorbed H2O and benzaldehyde species (FS2). The energy barrier for this step is 1.37 eV, but the desorption energy of benzaldehyde species is as high as 1.47 eV, suggesting that benzaldehyde is prone to over-oxidation on MVTN. The reaction pathway of over-oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid on the surface of MVTN shows that this step is easy to occur, with only an endothermic energy of 0.03 eV and a reaction energy barrier of 0.96 eV (Figs. 2(e) and 2(f)). On the contrary, upon 8 wt% of TeO x is loaded on the surface of MVTN (i.e., TeO x /MVTN), toluene is vertically adsorbed with its methyl toward surface and, similarly, one hydrogen on the methyl group is abstracted to the oxygen site on the nearby V, forming V–OH. And, the intermediate benzyl is adsorbed onto the oxygen of TeO x cluster nearby, forming C6H5–CH2–O–Te (FS1), with a reaction energy barrier of 2.04 eV. In the same way, the other hydrogen of intermediate FS1 is extracted to the V–OH site to form adsorbed H2O, and at this point, the adsorbed benzaldehyde species is located on the TeO x cluster (FS2). Although the reaction energy barrier for this step is 2.07 eV, the desorption energy of benzaldehyde species is as low as 0.64 eV, implying that the generated benzaldehyde is more easily desorbed on TeO x /MVTN. If benzaldehyde is excessively oxidized to benzoic acid, an endothermic energy of 0.69 eV is required (Figs. 2(f) and 2(g)), which is 23 times higher than on the surface of MVTN. The calculation results of higher cutoff energy also show the same trend (Tables S1 and S2). These facts demonstrate that the construction of TeO x clusters at appropriate position on the surface of MVTN not only effectively covers the active sites of toluene over-oxidation, but also regulates the dominant configuration of toluene adsorption in a vertical manner with its methyl toward surface. At the same time, the active centers undergo electron rearrangement due to the strong interaction between TeO x and MVTN, significantly weakening the adsorption of the product benzaldehyde, thereby achieving high selectivity for benzaldehyde. 3.2 Structures and active sites of MVTN and TeOx/MVTN The MVTN catalyst was prepared by an improved hydrothermal process, followed by impregnation of telluric acid on MVTN and calcination to obtain TeO x /MVTN catalyst with a TeO x of 8 wt%, according to surface density of about 0.34 TeO x clusters per nm2 (Fig. S5). Both the MVTN and TeO x /MVTN, as observed by scanning and transmission electron microscopy, display the structures of long fragmented block shapes with sizes ranging from hundreds of nanometers to micrometers (Figs. S6(a‒d)). From the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images, both of them appear (200) facet of M1 crystal (Figs. 3(a) and 3(b) ). Meanwhile, the corresponding EDS-mapping images of them imply that all elements are uniformly dispersed, including post-loaded TeO x (Figs. S6(e) and 6(f)). XRD results suggest that the two catalysts mainly present M1 crystal phase and the loaded TeO x is highly dispersed (Fig. S7). Fig. 3(c) depicts the Raman spectra of MVTN and TeO x /MVTN. All the scattering peaks can be ascribed to the vibration modes documented [55,56], such as MoO3 (∼243 and ∼324 cm−1), Mo‒O (I) and Mo–O (II) groups in MoO2 lattice (∼614 and ∼741 cm−1), asymmetric Mo‒O‒Mo/V bridge stretching mode (∼862 cm−1), and stretching vibration of terminal Mo=O and/or V=O bonds (∼940 cm−1). By loading TeO x , the relative intensities of the bands at ∼862 and ∼940 cm−1, relevant to Mo‒O‒V and V=O bonds, respectively, are obviously weakened, supporting the abovementioned points that the loaded TeO x is mainly aggregated around vanadium oxide sites. For FT-IR spectra shown in Fig. 3(d), the stretching vibrations (∼876 and ∼563 cm−1) of MoO3 with a layer-type structure as well as the symmetric stretching vibration (∼763 cm−1) and the doubly degenerated antisymmetric stretching vibration (∼629 cm−1) of Te–O bond are observed on MVTN [57,58]. After loading TeO x , the vibrations associated with Te–O bond significantly shift towards lower wavenumbers, however, the vibrations assigned to MoO3 are little changed; meanwhile, a new band (∼902 cm−1) attributed to Te‒O‒M (M = Mo or V) linkages become apparent [59]. These facts imply that the loaded TeO x is different from that of the original Te in MVTN and locates at the surface points between Mo‒O and V‒O sites. H2-TPR results confirm that the movable oxygen amount of TeO x /MVTN is significantly less than MVTN. Accordingly, the results of NH3-TPD and pyridine-IR (Figs. S8 and S9, Table S3) demonstrate that the TeO x on MVTN surface shield most weak Lewis acid sites, meanwhile, the amount of strong Lewis acid sites increases mainly due to the contribution of TeO x . By loading TeO x , the EPR signal with an isotropic g value of 1.954 ascribed to V4+ species is greatly enhanced (Fig. 3(e)) [60–62], indicating the strong interaction between TeO x and vanadium oxide sites, in accordance with Raman and FT-IR results. Similar phenomenon can also be concluded from XPS of TeO x /MVTN (Fig. 3(f)), of which the V 2p peak intensity is only about half that of MVTN (Fig. S10(a)), implying the covering of loaded TeO x above the vanadium oxide sites on the surface of MVTN. The relative concentration of V4+ on the surface of TeO x /MVTN increases compared with MVTN, indicating electron transfer from loaded TeO x to vanadium. The peak intensity of Mo 3d, however, remains almost unchanged before and after loading TeO x on the surface of MVTN, but surprisingly, the relative concentration of Mo6+ species significantly increases on the surface of TeO x /MVTN (Figs. S10(a) and 10(b)). This indicates that the loaded TeO x is hardly located on molybdenum oxide sites but may interact with the molybdenum sites from side. Similarly, the electron binding energies of niobium keep unchanged between the two catalysts, implying weak interactions between the loaded TeO x and niobium sites (Fig. S10(c)). The binding energies of Te 3d (Fig. S10(d)) suggest it is mainly in a +4 valence state on MVTN but changes to mixed oxidation states of +4/+6 on the surface of TeO x /MVTN. These suggest that the loaded TeO x strongly interacts with the surface of MVTN and causes electron transfers, e.g., Mo → V and Mo → Te. Considering the concentration of Te on the surface TeO x /MVTN increases to about three times, compared with that on MVTN (Fig. S1), and combining the calculation results, it can be concluded that the loaded TeO x reconstructs the surface MVTN with TeO x small clusters located above vanadium sites and side interacted with molybdenum sites (Figs. S7, 3(c) and 3(d)), decreasing the surface concentration of nucleophilic oxygen species (∼530.1 eV) but increasing that of electrophilic oxygen species (∼531.6 eV) (Fig. S10(e) and Table S4) [63,64]. The calculation shows that the Bader charge of surface vanadium increases by +0.07 |e| after loading TeO x clusters on the surface of MVTN, which is in consistent with the XPS results of V 2p (Figs. S11 and 3(f)). It appears the surface is rearranged by the loading of TeO x , one of the original components, on MVTN around the V species. The V K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES, Fig. 3(g)) implies that the loading of TeO x on MVTN decreases the valence state of V, in consistent with the XPS results of V 2p binding energy (Fig. 3(f)). The V K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS, Fig. 3(h)) and corresponding curve fitting results (Table S5) suggest that the V–O and V–O–V bonds are shortened in TeO x /MVTN compared with MVTN, which can be more clearly shown in the corresponding wavelet transform (WT, Fig. 3(i)) maps, exhibiting an obvious high-k shift of V–O intensity maximum from ∼10.5 Å−1 (MVTN) to ∼12.4 Å−1 (TeO x /MVTN) [65]. Meanwhile, it is found that there exists V–O–Te bond on TeO x /MVTN with a coordination number of approximately ∼0.4 (Table S5) according to the well nonlinear least-squares fitting (Fig. S12(a)) as well as the significant enhancement in V–O–V/Te intensity maximum (Fig. 3(i)). These phenomena suggest that the vanadium oxide sites in MVTN exhibit strong electronic interaction with the loaded TeO x clusters. The Mo K-edge XANES, EXAFS, and nonlinear least-squares fitting results (Figs. S12(b) and S13, Table S5) suggest that the valence state of Mo increases after the loading of TeO x clusters on MVTN, in agreement with the XPS results of Mo 3d (Fig. S10(b)). Meanwhile, similar Mo–O and Mo–O–Mo shells indicate that the loading of TeO x has a weak effect on the overall structure of molybdenum oxide sites in MVTN. By contrast, the Te K-edge XANES spectra (Fig. 3(j)) demonstrate that the valence state of Te is between +4 and +6 but closer to +6 valence on TeO x /MVTN compared with MVTN, in consistent with the XPS results of Te 3d (Fig. S10(d)). Moreover, its corresponding EXAFS and curve fitting results (Figs. 3(k) and S13(c), Table S5) indicate that a new Te–O–V bond, with a coordination number of approximately ∼0.5, is formed by loading TeO x clusters on MVTN, which can be further proved by a significant low-k shift of Te–O intensity maximum from ∼8.8 Å−1 (MVTN) to ∼6.1 Å−1 (TeO x /MVTN) in the corresponding WT maps (Fig. 3(l)). These facts demonstrate that the local structure of the loaded TeO x clusters is completely different from that of Te in MVTN, in agreement with the results of FT-IR (Fig. 3(d)). And there is a strong electronic interaction between TeO x clusters and V as well as Mo in MVTN, demonstrating the loading of TeO x clusters brings about a rearrangement of the electronic structure of TeO x /MVTN. Based on the comprehensive calculation and characterization results, it is reasonably to infer that post loaded TeO x highly disperses on the surface of MVTN as isolated small clusters surrounding and strongly interacting to the vanadium oxide sites with newly formed Te–O–V bonds. As to the relation between the post TeO x and the molybdenum, given that the high impossibility of the location of the TeO x clusters over molybdenum oxide in terms of the experiments, there is a lateral electronic interaction between them in a relatively farther distance, compared with vanadium. These points are in consistent with the properties of toluene reaction (see below) and related DFT calculations. 3.3 Catalytic test and kinetics The catalytic performances and kinetics of MVTN and TeO x /MVTN with different loading of TeO x for selective oxidation of toluene by O2 were evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor (Figs. 4(a–h) and S14). As shown in Fig. 4(a), over pure MVTN, toluene undergoes over-oxidation to generate a large amount of maleic anhydride (∼65%) and CO x (∼28%), and no benzaldehyde is detected at 400 °C. In contrast, once moderate TeO x is loaded on MVTN surface, the catalyst delivers a remarkable toluene conversion up to ∼24% with a high selectivity of >95% to benzaldehyde, demonstrating that the over-oxidation of toluene is almost totally suppressed by the loading of TeO x . The effect of reaction temperature on catalytic performances of the two catalysts are shown in Figs. S14(a) and 14(b). With the increase in the loading of TeO x , the selectivity to benzaldehyde gradually increases from zero and the selectivity to maleic anhydride and CO x decrease gradually (Figs. 4(b) and S14(c)), very clearly, the channel of the surface reaction of toluene switches from maleic anhydride and CO x to benzaldehyde upon the post loading of TeO x . During the switching, benzoic acid shows as a transition product, with its selectivity increases at the first and then decreases with the increase in loading of TeO x . This indicates that the oxidation of toluene to maleic anhydride complies with the following steps: toluene → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid → maleic anhydride [66]. It is interesting that the ratio of O2/toluene in reactant has little influence on the toluene reaction on TeO x /MVTN, in the range of 10–50 (Fig. 4(c)). With the increase of reaction space velocity, the selectivity to benzaldehyde is significantly improved, while the decreasing trend of toluene conversion is relatively less obvious (Fig. 4(d)), and the space time yield of benzaldehyde reaches 23.1 mg·gCat. −1·h−1 (Fig. S14(d)). Moreover, the catalytic performance of TeO x /MVTN keeps stable in prolonged time of reaction (>560 h) with the selectivity to benzaldehyde always > 95% (Fig. 4(e)). Scheme S1, Table S6, and Figs. 4(f–h) show the results of reaction kinetics of toluene oxidation over the current catalysts. Scheme S1 displays the reaction routes of the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde (rate coeﬃcient k 1), the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde to CO x (rate coeﬃcient k 2), and the combustion of toluene to CO x (rate coeﬃcient k 3), respectively, over MVTN and TeO x /MVTN. The ratio of k 1/k 3 on TeO x /MVTN exceeds 330, which is about 136 times those of MVTN (Table S6), suggesting that the toluene combustion reaction is significantly inhibited on TeO x /MVTN. As shown in Fig. 4(f), the apparent activation energy of benzaldehyde formation over MVTN (40.8 kJ·mol−1) is much lower than that of toluene conversion (60.2 kJ·mol−1), suggesting that the benzaldehyde generated on MVTN is more easily activated than the reactant toluene. In contrast, the apparent activation energies of toluene conversion (105.7 kJ·mol−1) and benzaldehyde formation (103.3 kJ·mol−1) over TeO x /MVTN are similar, both are significantly larger than over MVTN, implying that the oxidation pathway of toluene on TeO x /MVTN is completely different from that on MVTN. Here, the activation energy of toluene on TeO x /MVTN is close to twice that on MVTN, which is consistent with the change tendency of reaction energy barriers required for the first dehydrogenation of toluene between the two catalysts obtained by DFT calculations. Meanwhile, compared to MVTN (71.8 kJ·mol−1), the larger apparent activation energy of maleic anhydride formation on TeO x /MVTN (103.1 kJ·mol−1) further indicates that toluene is easier to generate maleic anhydride on MVTN than on TeO x /MVTN, which is consistent with the results calculated by DFT. As summarized in Figs. 4(g) and 4(h), over the two catalyst, it appears the range of kinetics control for the reaction is with toluene pressure less than 0.021 bar and the oxygen pressure less than 0.17 bar. For MVTN, the slopes of lnr with lnP toluene or lnP O2 are measured as 0.84 or 0.59, respectively. In the range of higher pressures, however, the reaction rate shows a zero-order dependence on the pressure of toluene or O2, suggesting that the reaction sites have been saturated by the reactant adsorption at higher pressures. By contrast, both toluene and O2 exhibit lower order dependence on TeO x /MVTN than those on MVTN in the lower pressure range, which may be attributed to the slow consumption of dissociated toluene and oxygen species, resulting in a high coverage of toluene and oxygen species on TeO x /MVTN surface. This is consistent with the relative larger apparent activation energy of TeO x /MVTN compare to MVTN. In addition, excessive pressure will lead to a decrease in reaction rate, presumably due to the blocking effect of intermediate adsorption and the steric effect of TeO x [67], which is well supported by DFT calculations. Molecular dynamic (MD) simulations were further conducted to gain insight into the diffusion rates and adsorption-desorption of reaction molecules on MVTN and TeO x /MVTN. A 5 × 10 × 3 supercell of MoVTeNbO complex oxides was generated as MVTN, and TeO x clusters were partially loaded on the surface of the supercell to create TeO x /MVTN (Fig. S15). It is found that toluene is mainly adsorbed in a lying down form on the surface of MVTN, however, it tends to adsorb vertically after TeO x clusters partially covered on the surface of MVTN. The loading of TeO x clusters significantly weakens the adsorption of toluene, while promotes its faster desorption from the surface of catalyst (Fig. S16). These phenomena are well accordance with the results of DFT and in-situ DRIFTS measurements. Furthermore, the diffusion coefficients of toluene and oxygen under different partial pressures were fitted using mean square displacement (MSD) (Figs. 4(i) and 4(j), Table S7). It is found that the diffusion rates of toluene and O2 on the surface of MVTN firstly increase and then remain almost unchanged with increasing the pressures of the two molecules, however, the diffusion rates of the two molecules on the surface of TeO x /MVTN show a trend of firstly increasing and then decreasing under the same treatment conditions and their diffusion rates on TeO x /MVTN is much lower than those on MVTN (Figs. 4(k) and 4(l)), implying the partial covering of TeO x clusters on the surface of MVTN significantly affects the adsorption mode of toluene through steric effect, well consistent with DFT calculations and kinetics testing. 3.4 Catalyst mechanism revealed by in-situ spectroscopy In-situ DRIFTS as well as XPS analysis on catalysts treated with different reaction atmospheres were conducted to probe the evolution of surface species and electronic states of the catalysts during the reaction. For the in-situ DRIFTS of MVTN, the appearances of the C–H stretching vibration of aromatic ring (∼3002 cm−1), the asymmetric and symmetric C–H stretching vibrations of –CH2– (∼2920 and ∼2847 cm−1), the symmetric C=C stretching vibrations of aromatic ring (∼1615 cm−1), the C–C stretching vibrations of aromatic ring (∼1548 and ∼1450 cm−1), and the asymmetric and symmetric in-plane C–H bending vibrations of –CH3 (∼1394 and ∼1338 cm−1), accompanied by the enhancing intensities with the prolonged time at the initial stage of reaction, indicate that toluene molecules are adsorbed in a lying down form on MVTN (Fig. 5(a) and Table S8) [13,14,68,69]. Furthermore, some new bands appear: the two bonds at 1799 and 1764 cm−1, attributed to C=O stretching vibrations of anhydride; the band at 1054 cm−1, assigned to the C–O–C stretching vibration [70,71]. And, only a weak band ascribed to C=O stretching vibration of aldehyde can be detected [13]. These characteristics demonstrate that toluene is mainly oxidized to maleic anhydride on MVTN and the amount of benzaldehyde is very little. After moderate density of TeO x clusters are loaded on MVTN, as sharp contrast, the bands ascribed to the vibrations of aromatic ring (C–H, C=C, and C–C) cannot be detected (or are very weak), while some new bands assigned to the vibrations of aldehyde (C–H, C=O, C–CHO, and C–O) appear, along with the enhancing intensities with the prolonged time of reaction (Fig. 5(b) and Table S8) [72–75]. These phenomena are in line with that toluene is mainly vertically adsorbed with its methyl downward to TeO x /MVTN and the main product is benzaldehyde. It is worth noting that the intensities of bands attributed to carbon dioxide are very weak on MVTN but especially strong on TeO x /MVTN, this trend is seemly opposite to the production of carbon dioxide on the two catalysts, suggesting that the desorption of carbon dioxide from the over-oxidation active sites is very easy on MVTN, however, it is much harder on TeO x /MVTN, which helps to improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. That is, the adsorption energy of carbon dioxide on TeO x /MVTN is much higher than that on MVTN (Fig. 5(c)), calculated by DFT and in consistent with the results of in-situ DRIFTS. In addition, both the relative concentrations of +4-valent Te and +4-valent V significantly increase after the TeO x /MVTN is used in a stream of toluene/Ar under reaction conditions, but those of Mo and Nb with different valence states are not obviously changed. Meanwhile, the relative concentration of electrophilic oxygen species (OEos) on TeO x /MVTN also significantly increases after the treatment of TeO x /MVTN in a stream of toluene/Ar (Figs. 5(d) and S17, Table S9). These facts demonstrate that both the oxygen species of TeO x clusters and vanadium oxide sites participate in the activation and oxidation of toluene, in well accordance with the DFT calculations (Fig. 2). 3.5 Toluene homologues reactions over TeOx/MVTN The catalyst of TeO x /MVTN is found active and selective for wide scope of toluene homologues. o-Xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene exhibit higher conversion and yield than toluene, nevertheless, the selectivities of corresponding aldehydes are somewhat lower than that of benzaldehyde (Table 1 , entry 1‒4), conforming to the trade-off effect of conversion and selectivity. And the selectivities of corresponding aldehydes are obvious enhanced by increasing the reaction space velocity. For chlorine substituted toluene derivatives, the conversion of p-chlorotoluene reaches to ∼29% with a high selectivity of p-chlorobenzaldehyde over 99%, however, the conversion of o-chlorotoluene and m-chlorotoluene is lower than that of toluene (Table 1, entry 7‒9). In addition, nitro, amino, and hydroxyl substituted toluene derivatives undergo decomposition or polymerization on TeO x /MVTN during the reaction. It is worth noting that a volcanic type correlation between the Bader charges of H atoms and the yield of corresponding aldehydes can be observed (Fig. S18). DFT calculations were performed to explore the reaction mechanism of p-chlorotoluene oxidation over TeO x /MVTN, especially for the ultra-high selectivity to p-chlorobenzaldehyde (Fig. 6 ). Akin to the active sites of toluene oxidation on TeO x /MVTN, the V=O active site located at the pentameric ensembles (S4)2-S2-(S7)2 (I) was the adsorption site of p-chlorotoluene. Firstly, p-chlorotoluene is spontaneously vertically adsorbed on the adsorption site with a methyl downward direction (II), one hydrogen on the methyl group is abstracted to the oxygen site on the nearby V (TS1), forming V–OH. Subsequently, the reaction intermediate benzyl oxygen species is adsorbed onto the cluster oxygen of TeO x , forming Cl–C6H5–CH2–O–Te (FS1), with a reaction energy barrier of 2.02 eV, which is similar to the energy barrier of 2.04 eV for this step in toluene oxidation. Then, the other hydrogen of intermediate FS1 is extracted to the V–OH site (TS1) to form adsorbed H2O, and the adsorbed benzaldehyde species is located on the TeO x cluster (FS2), with a reaction energy barrier of 2.18 eV. Surprisingly, the desorption energy of p-chlorobenzaldehyde species is calculated as almost zero, which is far below the energy barrier of 0.64 eV for the desorption of benzaldehyde. If p-chlorobenzaldehyde is excessively oxidized to p-chlorobenzoic acid, an endothermic energy of 1.98 eV is required (Fig. S19). This precisely explains the reason for the ultra-high selectivity of p-chlorobenzaldehyde. After that, the p-chlorobenzaldehyde and H2O desorb to the gas phase to create two oxygen vacancies successively on TeO x /MVTN (III and IV). At the end, the molecular oxygen from the gas phase rapidly fills the oxygen vacancies and the TeO x /MVTN recovers. 4 Conclusions Highly selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde by directly using O2 as a green oxidant, without the use of H2O2, halogens, or any radical initiators, was achieved on TeO x clusters loaded MoVTeNbO composite oxide in a fixed bed reactor under ambient pressure. The process delivers remarkable toluene conversion of up to ∼24% while maintaining a high selectivity of >95% to benzaldehyde. The discrete TeO x clusters are deposited on surface of MoVTeNbO composite oxide surround the V=O sites and then the adsorption configuration of toluene on the rearranged surface of catalyst changes from lying flat to vertical adsorption with its methyl downward to TeO x /MoVTeNbO, which in turn significantly weakens the adsorption of the product benzaldehyde, thereby achieving high selectivity to benzaldehyde. The novel reaction mechanism reveals that the V=O active site located at the pentameric ensembles (S4)2-S2-(S7)2 is mainly responsible for the successive abstraction of the two hydrogens of the methyl group to form adsorbed OH and the TeO x clusters participate in the reaction to stabilize benzaldehyde by couple interaction of Te–O with –CHO. The newly demonstrated mechanism has been proved effective for toluene homologues oxidation to aldehyde, especially for xylene and chlorotoluene. This work not only enriches and deepens our understanding of typical catalytic oxidation processes, but also opens a promising route towards the design of highly efficient catalysts for green oxidation of hydrocarbons to oxygenated compounds. coredata.dc:description: The heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of toluene by O2 is an inherently safe and green route for production of benzaldehyde, but after more than fifty years of effort, it remains a great challenge. Here, we report the best heterogeneous catalyst, TeO x /MoVTeNbO, up to now for the green oxidation of toluene by O2 to benzaldehyde, balancing the catalyst activity, selectivity, and stability. The deposition of TeO x endows the MoVTeNbO composite oxide with entirely new property for toluene oxidation and the surface engineering mechanism has been fully explained. The discrete TeO x clusters on the surface, shielding the nonselective oxidation sites that interact strongly with the benzene ring of toluene molecule, allows toluene molecule to chemically adsorb to the surface perpendicularly and the methyl is then prone to oxidation to aldehyde on the reshaped selective oxidation sites, where V=O is the main active species responsible for continuously extracting hydrogen from methyl and implanting oxygen to form benzaldehyde. The TeO x clusters participate in this reaction through variable valences and stabilize benzaldehyde by couple interaction with the –CHO group of benzaldehyde, thereby achieving high selectivity to benzaldehyde (>95%). The extended works indicate that the catalytic mechanism is effective in a series of selective oxidation of toluene homologues to corresponding aldehydes.

coredata.dc:title: Surface engineering of TeO x modification on MoVTeNbO creates a high-performance catalyst for oxidation of toluene homologues to aldehydes
